document.masterDocTitle: New species and new records of the hermit crab genus Pagurixus Melin, 1939 (Crustacea: Decapoda: Anomura: Paguridae) from the Indo-West Pacific

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species and new records of the hermit crab genus Pagurixus Melin, 1939 (Crustacea: Decapoda: Anomura: Paguridae) from the Indo-West Pacific

caption.paragraph:
Figure 8.
Pagurixus icelus
sp. nov. holotype, male (shield length 1.27 mm; MNHN-Pg 8302). (A) Shield and cephalic appendages, dorsal view; (B) ultimate segment and ventral flagellum of left antennule, ventromesial view; (C) right second pereopod, lateral view; (D) right second pereopod, dactylus, mesial view; (E) right second pereopod, carpus, mesial view; (F) left third pereopod, lateral view; (G) left third pereopod, dactylus, mesial view; (H) left fourth pereopod, lateral view; (I) right fourth pereopod, lateral view; (J) sixth thoracic sternite, ventral view; (K) coxae of fifth pereopods and eighth thoracic sternite, ventral view; (L) telson, dorsal view. Notes: Scale bars, (A, C, D, G) 0.5 mm; (B, H–L) 0.25 mm.

Figure 9.
Pagurixus icelus
sp. nov. holotype, male (shield length 1.27 mm; MNHN-Pg 8302). (A) Right chela and carpus, dorsal view; (B) right cheliped, mesial view; (C) right cheliped, lateral view; (D) left chela and carpus, dorsal view; (E) left cheliped, mesial view; (F) left cheliped, lateral view. Note: Scale bar, 0.5 mm.

Figure 10.
Pagurixus icelus
sp. nov. holotype, ovigerous female (shield length 1.05 mm; MNHN-Pg 8308). (A) Right chela and carpus, dorsal view; (B) right cheliped, mesial view; (C) right cheliped, lateral view; (D) left third pereopod, lateral view. Note: Scale bar, 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Male right cheliped ( Figure 9A–C ) massive, not particularly elongate. Chela 1.5–1.7 times longer than wide. Dactylus longer than palm, directed somewhat downward, terminating in calcareous claw; convex dorsal surface granular, dorsomesial margin not delimited; mesial face sparsely granular, ventral surface nearly smooth; cutting edge with one low, obtuse calcareous teeth on proximal half. Palm widened distally, subequal in length to carpus; dorsal surface convex, finely granular; dorsolateral margin not delimited on palm; dorsomesial margin sharply delimited with crenulate edge; lateral, mesial and ventral surfaces finely granular. Fixed finger somewhat curving downward, terminating in calcareous claw; lateral margin faintly delimited by row of granules; cutting edge with one obtuse calcareous tooth proximal to midlength. Carpus subequal in length to merus, length 1.0–1.1 times distal width, finely granular on surfaces; dorsal surface with few small tubercles and spiniform setae dorsomesially; sloping lateral surface lacking longitudinal ridge; ventral surface convex, without prominent setae on distal margin. Meral–carpal articulation lacking any pronounced clockwise rotation; dorsal surface of merus smooth, dorsodistal margin with few short setae; lateral face finely granular, ventrolateral margin unarmed; mesial face smooth, convex ventromesial margin unarmed; ventral surface smooth, with few long setae. Ischium with smooth ventromesial margin; surfaces smooth.

In preservative. No markings seen on shield and cephalic appendages. Right cheliped generally cream, palm with reddish brown spot at proximomesial angle; tubercles on mesial part of carpus reddish-brown; merus with thin transverse band subdistally. Propodi of ambulatory legs white in distal 0.2, each with three brownish longitudinal stripes on lateral surface not extending to distal white part; carpi also with one brownish longitudinal stripe on lateral surface.
Largest male SL 1.4 mm , largest female SL 1.1 mm , ovigerous females SL 1.0– 1.1 mm .

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Known only from the Austral Islands , French Polynesia , at depths of
2–9 m
. Etymology

subSubSection.paragraph:
From the Greek ikelos meaning like or resembling, in reference to the similarities shared with other species of the
Pagurixus anceps
group, such as
P. handrecki
and
P. fasciatus
.

Pagurixus icelus
sp. nov. closely resembles
P. handrecki Gunn and Morgan, 1992
and
P. fasciatus
in having a sharply delimited dorsomesial margin of the palm of the male right cheliped. In addition, these three species can have five or more small corneous spines on the ventral surface of each ambulatory propodus, although the number of spines is fairly variable. This new species is readily distinguished from
P. handrecki
by the ornamentation and armament of the right cheliped. The carpus of the right cheliped bears only a few tiny dorsomesial spines and spiniform setae in
P. icelus
, rather than having several moderately strong dorsomesial spines and dorsolateral spinulose tubercles (male) or moderately strong dorsolateral spines (female) in
P. handrecki
; the female right chela has smooth or granular dorsolateral and dorsomesial margins in
P. icelus
, whereas those margins are substantially spinose in
P. handrecki
(cf. Gunn and Morgan 1992 , figure 3c–e); the ventrolateral and ventromesial margins of the merus are unarmed in
P. icelus
, while armed with a row of spines in
P. handrecki .
Furthermore, the carpus of the left cheliped lacks dorsolateral spines in the new species, whereas such spines are present in
P. handrecki
. From
P. fasciatus
, the new species differs in the more stout ocular peduncles and the absence of dorsolateral spines on the carpus of the left cheliped. Furthermore, the coxa of the right fifth pereopod is devoid of a posteromesial protrusion in
P. icelus
, which is developed in
P. fasciatus
.

With regard to general colouration,
P. icelus
and
P. handrecki
are similar in having longitudinal stripes on the propodi of the ambulatory legs. Differences in colouration in life between the new species and
P. handrecki
could not be assessed because no information on living specimens was available for
P. icelus
.
Pagurixus fasciatus
differs from the two relatives in the distal three segments generally dark brown with white rings at the distal parts of the propodi and at the articulations between the propodi and carpi.
